Threat: Sensitive data is compromised though attacks against SSL/TLS
Mitigation: Require cryptographically strong TLS cipher suites. Require cryptographically secure protocols (e.g. TLSv1.2 and above)

Threat: Attackers obtain unauthorised access by connecting directly to the service
Mitigation: Require authentication before presenting restricted data

Threat: Attackers gain access to unauthorised data by exploiting vulnerabilities in the service
Mitigation: Apply required security patches to the service. Restrict access to the service at the network layer to reduce exposure.

Threat: Attackers gain unauthorised access to data and/or systems through SQL Injection attacks
Mitigation: Validate all data received from the client side. Use prepared statements for all database queries. Log and reject all data validation failures.

Threat: Authenticated attackers could gain unauthorised access to sensitive data
Mitigation: Apply authorisation checks to segregate and control access to user data

Threat: Anonymous users could gain access to sensitive data
Mitigation: Apply authorisation checks to segregate and control access to user data. Authenticate users (single factor authentication) or authenticate users (multi- or two-factor authentication [2FA])

Threat: Attackers gain access to data or services by directly accessing the resources
Mitigation: Apply authorisation checks to segregate and control access to user data

Threat: Sensitive data is exposed to unauthorised personnel in a pre-production environment
Mitigation: Ensure personal and other sensitive data is not exposed in pre-production environments

Threat: Sensitive data is compromised through network sniffing attacks
Mitigation: Encrypt data between the client and server/service

Threat: Attackers obtain unauthorised access by connecting directly to the service
Mitigation: Require authentication before presenting restricted data

Threat: Sensitive data is compromised though attacks against SSL/TLS
Mitigation: Require cryptographically strong TLS cipher suites

Threat: Attackers gain access to critical functions by compromising the session ID
Mitigation: Terminate user sessions on the server-side after a logout operation. Require additional authentication for sensitive operations / high value transactions.

Threat: Attackers could compromise users' sessions by compromising the session cookie
Mitigation: Session ID's should be transmitted securely. Session cookie domain attributes should be restricted to prevent exposure. Session cookie path attributes should be restricted to prevent exposure.

Threat: Attackers gain access to the system using default passwords
Mitigation: Remove default credentials and role-based accounts from the application

Threat: The session ID, and hence the users' session is compromised through brute force attack
Mitigation: Use session management functionality provided by the development framework. Session tokens should contain sufficient entropy.

Threat: Dictionary-based or brute force password attack
Mitigation: The login function should distinguish between upper and lower case passwords. Offer a password change facility. Require the use of strong passwords. Authenticate users (multi- or two-factor authentication [2FA]).

Threat: Session ID's and hence user sessions are compromised through network sniffing or man in the middle attacks
Mitigation: Set the 'secure' flag (or directive) on sensitive cookies

Threat: Attackers gain access to user accounts by accessing the password database
Mitigation: Store passwords in unrecoverable form to prevent disclosure

Threat: Attackers gain access to user accounts by exploiting flaws in the authentication function
Mitigation: Enforce authentication on the server-side. Ensure authentication fails securely on the serverside.

Threat: User accounts compromised through username guessing
Mitigation: Require the use of strong passwords. Implement application and network rate limiting on the login function.

Threat: Sensitive data is compromised through network access
Mitigation: Use Network Access Control Lists (NACLs) for blacklisting

Threat: Authentication credentials compromised through network sniffing
Mitigation: Encrypt data between the client and server/service

Threat: Attackers gain access to the systems through direct access
Mitigation: Use security groups to block ingress to all ports from 0.0.0.0/0. Restrict all traffic with the default security group.

Threat: Usernames could be enumerated through login responses
Mitigation: Ensure application errors do not reveal account status. Ensure failed login timings do not reveal account status.

Threat: Attacks against the authentication system may go undetected
Mitigation: Log details of user actions within the system. Use a synchronised time source.

Threat: Attackers gain unauthorised access to data or services by exploiting known weaknesses in components, libraries, modules, frameworks, platforms and operating systems
Mitigation: Regularly check all components of your project for known vulnerabilities

Threat: Attackers gain control of the system through a source code leakage
Mitigation: Prevent unauthorised access to source code through the service

Threat: Attackers gain unauthorised access to data on EC2 instances
Mitigation: Maintain a patch policy and patch EC2 systems regularly

Threat: Attackers gain access to the system through Server Side Code Injection
Mitigation: Validate all data received from external systems

Threat: Functionality could be subverted through mass assignment
Mitigation: Use a white-list approach to assign values to variables

Threat: Execute arbitrary code on the server by manipulating parameters
Mitigation: Use a library that is not vulnerable to Remote File Inclusion. Create a mapping to existing objects. Validate all data received from the client side. Log and reject all data validation failures. Validate input parameters to prevent HTTP Parameter Pollution. Verify that all input is limited to an appropriate size limit.

Threat: Attackers gain control of the connection by doing a Man In The Middle attack
Mitigation: Encrypt data between the client and server/service

Threat: User data or credentials are compromised through network sniffing or man in the middle attacks
Mitigation: Consider HTTP Public Key Pinning (HPKP). Encrypt data between the client and server/service. Set the HTTP security header 'Strict-Transport-Security' (HSTS). Preload application URLs to vendor Strict Transport Security domain lists.

Threat: Access system files through XML related Attacks
Mitigation: Disable external XML entity references in the processor. Define and enforce secure validation through an XSD or DSD schema on XML input data.

Threat: Unauthorised data could be accessed by manipulating the parameters sent to the application
Mitigation: Log and reject all data validation failures. Validate input parameters to prevent HTTP Parameter Pollution. Validate all data received from the client side. Verify that all input is limited to an appropriate size limit. Avoid using direct references to files. Disable Server Side Includes.

Threat: Sensitive data is compromised through query parameters in the URL
Mitigation: Ensure no sensitive data is sent in the URL

Threat: Attackers with access to a victim's browser could read locally stored data
Mitigation: Set Cache-Control headers on sensitive and authenticated content. Disable autocompletion of sensitive data. Do not store sensitive data on client side. Clear sensitive and authenticated data from client-side storage.

Threat: Sensitive data is compromised though attacks against SSL/TLS
Mitigation: Require cryptographically strong TLS cipher suites. Require cryptographically secure protocols (e.g. TLSv1.2 and above).

Threat: Authentication process is spoofed by replaying login credentials
Mitigation: Respond to login requests with HTTP 302 redirect. Disable authentication form autocomplete.

Threat: Attackers gain access to in-memory passwords/credentials
Mitigation: Overwrite passwords, key material, and other secrets maintained in memory when no longer required

Threat: Attackers with access to a victim's client could read locally stored credentials
Mitigation: Disable authentication form autocomplete / pre-fill

Threat: Attackers bypass authentication implemented on the client side
Mitigation: Enforce authentication on the server-side

Threat: Attackers gain unauthorised access to data or services by accessing a client side secret
Mitigation: Implement sensitive logic and data validation on the server-side. Review code, configuration, and online repositories for secrets and sensitive information systemically.

Threat: Attackers gain unauthorised access to data or services by exploiting known weaknesses in components, libraries, modules or frameworks
Mitigation: Regularly check all components of your project for known vulnerabilities

Threat: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a too permissive CORS policy
Mitigation: Restrict Cross Domain Origin policy through HTTP headers

Threat: Data is posted to a spoofed server
Mitigation: Encrypt data between the client and server/service

Threat: Attackers could gain access to an open session, if they have access to a user's browser
Mitigation: Revoke user sessions after a period of inactivity. Revoke user sessions after a fixed time period. Provide logout links on all pages that require authentication.

Threat: Attackers could gain access to a users' browser through Cross Site Scripting attacks
Mitigation: Terminate user sessions on the server-side. Perform contextual HTML encoding of all user submitted data. Set the HTTP security header 'X-Content-Type-Options' from the server. Set the 'httpOnly' flag (or directive) on session cookies. Define a restrictive 'least privilege' Content Security Policy. Set the HTTP security header 'X-XSS-Protection' from the server.

Threat: Attackers could cause users to perform specific actions on their behalf through Cross Site Request Forgery attacks
Mitigation: Set and verify one time 'Anti CSRF' tokens for sensitive operations. Require re-authentication for critical operations.

Threat: Attackers cause users to perform arbitrary clicks on the Critical site through ClickJacking attacks
Mitigation: Set the HTTP security header 'X-Frame-Options header' from the server
